p: In South and Central America, the last confirmed equine outbreak was reported in Brazil in 2007 and a prevalence of 36.4% has been reported in non-vaccinated horses in the Pantanal region of Brazil in 2010 and 0.4% in 2015. 14 The disease is suspected but has not been confirmed in other countries such as Bolivia and Costa Rica. In Uruguay, a fatal human case in 2009 associated with WEE virus encephalitis in a child led to a seroprevalence survey in this country, which revealed a low prevalence of this virus in horses ranging from 3% to 4%. 16, 17
